# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Special Instructions

None.

```julia
function wrap_string(text::AbstractString, text_width::Int=10)
    lines = []
    current_line = ""
    for word in split(text, ' ')
        if length(current_line) + length(word) + 1 > text_width # add 1 for the space
            push!(lines, current_line)
            current_line = word
        else
            current_line *= " $word"
        end
    end
    if current_line != ""
        push!(lines, current_line)
    end
    return join(lines, "\n")
end

# Example usage:
text = "Hello there this is a very long sentence that needs to be wrapped at a maximum width of 10 characters per line."
println(wrap_string(text))
```

This function splits the text into words using whitespace as a delimiter and then builds an array of lines by adding each word to the current line until the line length exceeds `text_width`, at which point a new line is started. The `+ 1` in the conditional accounts for the space between words.

The final result is a string with each line containing no more than `text_width` characters (including spaces), and each word starting a new line if it would cause the line length to exceed `text_width`.
